title: Graph Neural Networks for Financial Fraud and Anomaly Detection - Evidence Sheet
known_pitfalls: heterophily_assumption: fraud graphs inherently heterophilic (>35% fraudsters have 100% heterophilic edges)
class_imbalance: fraud is rare (0.1-0.3%); naive classifiers achieve 99%+ accuracy
ground_truth_accuracy: Elliptic dataset labeled via heuristics not ground truth
temporal_leakage: training on future data inflates metrics
graph_leakage: using future node attributes or edges inflates performance
auc_roc_insensitivity: 0.93 AUC on 0.1% fraud rate approximately equals predicting all negative
precision_recall_unreported: papers omit trade-off curves
hyperparameter_tuning_instability: 2-5% metric variance from small changes
concept_drift_not_evaluated: historical models degrade on recent data
inference_cost_underestimated: SHAP adds 5-20x latency overhead
sample_selection_bias: public datasets may not represent real patterns
adversarial_robustness_unknown: GNN robustness to adaptive fraudsters untested
memory_explosion: edge calculation generates order-of-magnitude intermediate results
graph_sampling_accuracy_loss: sampling trades 2-5% accuracy for speed
heterophily_mitigation_cost: spectral filtering 20-30% slower
explainability_accuracy_tradeoff: self-explainable models sacrifice 5-10% accuracy
temporal_granularity_choice: optimal aggregation method unclear
baseline_inconsistency: inconsistent preprocessing and metrics
reproducibility_gaps: hyperparameters and splits often not reported
imbalanced_evaluation: standard splits cause majority class overfitting
data_augmentation_artifacts: SMOTE creates unrealistic patterns
cold_start_problem: poor performance on new users with few connections
feature_engineering_overhead: end-to-end cost inflated by hand-crafted features
distribution_shift: Year 1 models degrade >10% on Year 3 data
regulatory_compliance_gap: black-box GNNs not deployable without explainability

notes: Comprehensive evidence sheet from 80 papers on GNN-based financial fraud detection. Covers credit card fraud (IEEE-CIS, Kaggle), cryptocurrency AML (Elliptic), stock market anomalies (NASDAQ/NYSE). Quantitative metrics extracted from peer-reviewed papers, arXiv preprints, and competition leaderboards. All metric ranges and performance baselines represent observed results in literature 2019-2025.
